Creating a Server Configuration

Before creating a server configuration, you need to decide upon a unique name for the configuration. This name is case insensitive and cannot contain colons (:), back slashes (\), or forward slashes (/), but can contain blanks or apostrophes ( ' ).

You must also set up the database to be used with the server configuration. A database can contain only one server configuration; however, other applications can share a database with StarTeam.

The Server places server log files in the location specified as the repository path. When you first start a new server configuration, the Server creates the Attachments folder, HiveIndex, and other folders in the same location. These folders are maintained by the Server; do not delete them. Paths to some of these folders can be changed with the Server Administration dialog.

For new server configurations, the initial hive is created at the same time as the server configuration. The user supplies an archive path and a cache path. The default paths are repository_path\DefaultHive\Archives and repository_path\DefaultHive\Cache. If desired, the location of these paths can be changed by using the Hive Manager dialog. All new files are added to a hive, even if the existing files have not been converted and remain in the Native-I format.

A single server configuration can have several hives, each of which has its own archive and cache path.

To create a new server configuration.

  1. On a computer that has the Server installed, select Start > Programs > StarTeam > StarTeam Server x.x > StarTeam Server. This action displays the Server Administration dialog.

  2. From the Server Administration dialog, do one of the following:

    • Click the Configure Server shortcut.

    • From the menu, select Tools > Administration > Configure Server.

      • These actions display the Configure Server dialog.

  3. Click New. This action displays the Create a New Configuration dialog.

  4. Enter a unique name in the Configuration Name text box.

  5. In the Repository Path text box, enter or browse for the location.

  6. Select a database type from the Database type list box. The selections include Microsoft SQL Server/MSDE and Oracle. The database type cannot be changed after the server configuration has been created.

  7. Select or deselect the Create new StarTeam database and ODBC data source. The default is selected.

  8. In the Initial Hive Settings, select the Default or Custom hive option.

  9. If you select the Default hive, changing the repository path changes the default hive settings. Changing the repository path does not have this effect if you select a Custom hive.

  10. If you are creating a Custom hive, you can override the default hive settings. You can change any of the following fields:

    • Name: Unique name for the hive. DefaultHive is the default.

    • Archive path: Path to the hive's Archives directory. The default is <repository_path\DefaultHive\Archives.

    • Cache path: Path to the hive's Cache directory. The default is <repository_path\DefaultHive\Cache.

    • Maximum cache size: Maximum number of megabytes of hard disk space that the Cache can use. The default is 20% of the disk space available when the option is set.

    • Cache cleanup interval: Seconds between cache cleanup/refresh operations. The default value is 600. The range is 60 (1 minute) to 3153600 (1 year).

    • Storage limit threshold: Percentage of total disk space allowed for hive. When this percentage has been reached, no more archives can be added to the hive. The default is 95% of the total disk space.

  11. Click Next. This action displays the first screen in the Create a [Database] Database dialog. The information that must be entered here (and on any following screens) varies according to the database you have selected.

  12. After the new server configuration has been completed, it appears in the Server Administration dialog with the status of New. Select the configuration, and click Start Server. The Server then initializes the database and creates the required server configuration files and folders. See Starting and Stopping a Server Configuration.

  13. When the server finishes this activity, the Status column for the server configuration changes from New to Running.  

  14. Finally, click Modifying a Server Configuration for information on how to review and, if required, change the default configuration options.
